results.title: Children of Peru
results.creator_credit: Michael Andrews and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Documents new agricultural methods and technological discoveries in Peru and the beneficial effects these might have on the health and nutrition of the children of Peru if implemented. Narrated by paul Vaughan. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Children of paradise = Les Enfants du paradis
results.creator_credit: Marcel Carne, Raymond Borderie and Societe Nouvelle Pathe Cinema
results.brief_description: The film begins with the titles superimposed on a theatre curtain which, when it lifts, ushers us into the chaotic world of the “boulevard of crime” in the mid-nineteenth century. Mime artist Baptiste (Jean-Louis Barrault) is desperately in love with the beautiful Garance (Arletty), but she is too world-weary and cynical to believe in his romantic notions of love; instead she begins an affair with the vain actor, Frederick, who dreams of leaving the pantomimes and performing Shakespeare in the grand theatres of Paris. This magical movie, consistently voted the best French film of all time, is a celebration of art and love. While behind the scenes the actors all battle with the bitter realities of unrequited desire or betrayed trust, on stage, performing to the “children of paradise” (those too poor to afford seats in the stalls and so have to sit in the “Gods”), they transform their sadness into the magic of dreams. It is as if, in this film, Marcel Carne makes good on all the promises of film and theatre to create a truly popular art, and he does so by celebrating not only the lives of the actors and performers on the “boulevard”, but also by celebrating the dreams and desires of the raucous, struggling audience that fills the “gods”. In the bond between performer and audience we see reflected the pleasures and mistakes of love itself. The sophisticated screenplay is by Jacques Prevert. Considered one of the cinema’s supreme works of art, the film was partly secretly filmed while Paris was still under Nazi occupation. On all levels, a labour of immense love. Cast also includes Maria Casares and Pierre Renoir. In French with English subtitles.

results.creator_credit: Clyde E. Elliott and Post Pictures Corporation

results.title: Children of Japan
results.brief_description: A study of the daily life of a middle-class Japanese family immediately before World War II. The contrast between the influence of Western technology and the traditional customs and habits of the Japanese people is reflected in their environment.

results.title: Children of Hong Kong
results.creator_credit: Yvonne MacKay, Dave Gibson and Gibson Film Productions
results.brief_description: Looks at the life of a young boy Ying Kit, and his extended family in Hong Kong. The family live in a houseboat and the program looks at various aspects of his life such as school, family relationships, chores and food.

results.title: Children of heaven [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Majid Majidi, Mohammad Esfandiari, Amir Esfandiari and The Institute for the Intellectual Development of Children and Young Adults
results.brief_description: Iranian actor turned director, Majid Majidi, has enjoyed commercial and critical success for his humanist portrayals of contemporary Iranian society. “Children of heaven”, nominated for Best Foreign Language Film at the 1999 Academy Awards, is a simple yet tender film about a young boy, Ali, who accidentally loses his sister, Zahra’s, only pair of shoes immediately after having them repaired. Though Zahra is distraught, Ali convinces her not to tell their father, who is already burdened with the responsibilities of supporting a family, including a sick wife, on a meagre wage, and is prone to react violently and irrationally. They agree to keep the news hidden and to share Ali’s one pair of sneakers; an arrangement that involves Zahra rushing from a half day at school at midday to give Ali the sneakers in order for him to attend school in the afternoon. Throughout the film, Ali’s sustained efforts to organise his sister another pair of shoes are continually frustrated. Overall, “Children of heaven” is a poignant, sentimental portrait of class difference in Iran and the struggle of a poor family. It opts for simple imagery - including shots of nature and the children’s faces - to establish a sense of innocence and humanity about its story. It clearly posits the children as the hope of the future - Ali is the top student in his class as well as being physically superior and mature, whilst Zahra is virtuous and innocent. And despite their impoverished circumstances, their innocence ensure these children belong to heaven. In Farsi with English subtitles.

results.title: Children of Germany: in the Rhineland
results.creator_credit: Milan Herzog and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Four boys are shown on a day’s excursion in the Rhineland. As they sail with a pilot of a barge from Kaub to St Goar, navigation and the Rhine’s industrial importance are explained. The boys climb the Spitzenstein and see vineyards, potato patches, castles and historical villages of the Rhine.

results.title: Children of fire
results.creator_credit: Mai Masri, George Khleifi, Fatima Masri, BBC-TV and M T C
results.brief_description: Nablus, situated in the Israeli Occupied West Bank and home to 120,000 exiled Palestinians is also the home of filmmaker Mai Masri. It is 9 September 1989 and fourteen years since Mai has been in Nablus when she returns to her hometown to document Palestinian life since the beginning of the Intifada. Mai very quickly finds out that Nablus is not the peaceful town where she grew up - it is instead a place of violence, death, fear and tension, where young children have been robbed of their innocence and often their lives. The Palestinians in Nablus are constantly under survellience the Israeli Army which only serves to heighten the frustration and determination of the younger generation to fight for their freedom and confront the occupiers head-on, albeit with weapons of stones. Children as young as five are aware of their situation as exiles and from the ages of six and seven, many will become street-fighters, their games often replicating real life. Through these children’s personal stories and the violent images in their childish paintings, as well as some rather disturbing film footage of the Israeli soldiers in action, Mai Masri presents an uncompromising and courageous portrayal of Nablus and the children of the Intifada. (Awards: Cairo Television Festival 1995; Feminin Pluriel Festival) In English and Arabic with English subtitles.
